questions.question: Which of the following is not expected to increase as an immediate response to surgical stress or trauma?
questions.explanation: Insulin levels typically decrease in response to surgical stress or trauma due to the body's stress response, which includes the release of stress hormones such as cortisol and adrenaline that counteract the effects of insulin.

questions.question: The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
questions.explanation: The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient. Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes: Glasgow coma scale, Respiratory rate, Systolic BP. The score range is 0-12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury.

questions.question: Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS) includes which of the following components?
questions.explanation: TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) includes: Injury Severity Score (ISS), Revised Trauma Score (RTS), Age, and Mechanism of injury (blunt/penetrating).

questions.question: A 22-year-old man sustained a roller crush injury of his left arm up to mid-humerus and was brought to the casualty. The duty orthopedician uses the MESS score to decide about limb salvage. The score does not include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Neurogenic injury is not included in the Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS). The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is useful in deciding about limb salvage. The components of the Mangled Extremity Severity score are: the energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury, limb ischemia, shock, and age of the patient.

questions.question: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is being done in a patient with suspected hemoperitoneum. Which of the following statements is not true?

options.A: Presence of more than 100,000 RBCs/mm^3 is a positive finding
options.B: Presence of more than 200 white cells/mm^3 is a positive finding
options.C: Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy
options.D: Amylase levels more than 175 units/dL is a positive finding

questions.explanation: The presence of more than 500 white cells/mm^3 in blunt trauma indicates a positive finding of diagnostic peritoneal lavage. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage detects the presence of intraperitoneal blood. Its use has decreased to virtually nil at many centers with the advent of the FAST examination. Indications for diagnostic peritoneal lavage are: Abdominal pain or tenderness, low abdominal rib fractures, unexplained hypotension, spinal or pelvic fractures, paraplegia or quadriplegia, and assessment hampered by altered mental status due to neurologic injury or intoxication. Procedure: It is performed through a small infraumbilical incision with the placement of the catheter under direct vision. The supraumbilical approach is indicated in pregnant patients and those with pelvic fractures. Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy. If no blood is aspirated, a catheter is placed and 1 L of Ringer lactate solution is instilled into the peritoneal cavity and then allowed to drain by gravity. At least 200 mL of lavage fluid should be recovered to allow for accurate interpretation. Disadvantages: Neither qualitative nor quantitative, cannot identify the source of hemorrhage, relatively small amounts of intraperitoneal bleeding may result in a positive study, may not detect small and large injuries to the diaphragm, and cannot rule out injury to the bowel or retroperitoneal organs.

questions.question: A 32-year-old professional boxer was brought to the emergency department following a blow to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals were normal, and his abdomen was tender on palpation. Which among the following is the best modality to assess the injury to the abdominal organs for this patient?
questions.explanation: A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients with blunt trauma to the abdomen. It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify hemorrhage, intra-abdominal as well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients. FAST ultrasound is a limited examination directed to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.

questions.question: A young man is brought to the trauma unit following a road traffic accident. He is hemodynamically unstable. As an adjunct to the primary survey, the managing surgeon decides to do a FAST. Which of the following areas would not be visualized in this procedure?
questions.explanation: The left lower quadrant is not assessed in the FAST examination. FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. FAST also stands for Focused abdominal sonography for trauma. However, since FAST is not only used to assess abdominal injuries but also to assess hemopericardium in cases of pericardial injuries, the expansion Focused assessment with sonography for trauma is preferred. It can be performed within 2-4 minutes. Technique of FAST examination: With the patient in the supine position, a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used. Four regions may be scanned: Subxiphoid transverse view - to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries; Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant - to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morrison's pouch; Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant - to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury. Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region - to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas. In an extended FAST or eFAST scan, left and right thoracic views are used to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique?

options.A: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis
options.B: Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis → Pericardial sac
options.C: Pelvis → Pericardial sac → Perisplenic region → Perihepatic region
options.D: Perisplenic region → Perihepatic region → Pericardial sac → Pelvis

questions.explanation: The correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique is Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

questions.question: A patient with a history of blunt trauma is brought to the casualty and an eFAST examination is performed. Which of the following statements about the investigation is false?

options.A: B-lines indicate a normal ultrasonographic finding of the lung
options.B: Stratosphere sign seen in M-mode USG is indicative of pneumothorax
options.C: It can be reliably used to detect less than 100 mL of free blood
options.D: It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum

questions.explanation: FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood. Disadvantages of FAST: it does not directly identify injury to hollow viscus, cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma, and is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum. B-lines or 'comet trails' are echogenic bright linear reflections beneath the pleura that are usually lost with any air between the probe and the lung tissue. B-lines are expected in normal aerated lung and are visualized moving along with the sliding pleura. Excessive 'B-lines', especially in the anterior lung, are abnormal and are usually indicative of interstitial edema. Therefore, the presence of B-lines along with the seashore sign indicates the absence of pneumothorax. The stratosphere sign, also known as the barcode sign, and lack of sliding movement in the lungs diagnosed by an M-mode USG is suggestive of pneumothorax.

questions.question: An intensivist is evaluating a patient for brain stem death in the ICU. Presence of which of the following features should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function in this patient?
questions.explanation: Babinski reflex, tachycardia, and normal systolic blood pressure can be occasionally seen in patients with brain stem death. So, this should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function. Brain death is not characterized by decerebrate or decorticate posturing, which is a brain-originating motor response. Brainstem death is defined as the irreversible loss of cerebral and brain-stem function. Ideal criteria for brain stem death contain three essential elements: widespread cortical destruction that is reflected by deep coma and unresponsiveness to all forms of stimulation; global brainstem damage demonstrated by absent pupillary light reaction and by the loss of oculovestibular and corneal reflexes; and destruction of the medulla manifested by complete and irreversible apnea. Brainstem death entails testing twice, by two clinicians, to demonstrate the absence of: response to pain; respiratory drive (apnea despite arterial PCO2 ≥ 60 mm Hg); pupillary light reflex; corneal reflex; vestibulo-ocular reflex; and oculo-cephalic reflex. The following manifestations are occasionally seen in brain dead patients and should not be misinterpreted as evidence for brainstem function: movements originating from the spinal cord or peripheral nerve may occur; normal systolic blood pressure > 100 mmHg; sweating, flushing, tachycardia; deep tendon reflexes, superficial abdominal reflexes, triple flexion response; Babinski reflex; spontaneous movements of limbs other than pathologic flexion or extension response; and respiratory-like movements (shoulder elevation and adduction, back-arching, intercostal expansion without significant tidal volumes).

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient?

options.A: Hemodynamically unstable patients should not be sent for a CT scan
options.B: All patients should have a chest X-ray PA view only
options.C: X-ray of the pelvis is essential in the primary survey
options.D: X-rays in the primary survey must also be done in pregnant women

questions.explanation: Chest X-ray and X-ray of the pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

options.B: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
options.C: Taking a CT scan of the patient

questions.explanation: Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of the secondary survey. The primary survey identifies and manages the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. The secondary survey includes investigations that help identify all other injuries, excluding the apparent ones. This includes X-rays of the spine and extremities and a CT of the abdomen, head, chest, and spine.

questions.question: A patient who sustained an RTA was brought to the ER in a semiconscious state. He makes incoherent sounds, withdraws from painful stimuli, and opens his eyes to painful stimuli. Calculate his GCS score.
questions.explanation: The GCS score in this patient is 8. Withdraws from pain = 4, Incoherent sounds = 3, Opens eyes to painful stimuli = 2, however based on the given details it is 2 for eye opening and 2 for verbal, hence Total GCS score = 4 + 2 + 2 = 8.

questions.question: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS.
questions.explanation: The patient's GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6. It is calculated as follows: • Eye opening: Opening to verbal command - 3. • Verbal response: In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT (non-testable). • Motor response: Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6. Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered balanced resuscitation?

options.C: Maintaining pH by ensuring acid-base balance
options.D: Fluid resuscitation by giving colloids and crystalloids

questions.explanation: Permissive hypotension is a part of balanced resuscitation in trauma management to avoid bleeding. Damage control resuscitation (DCR), i.e., balanced resuscitation, is used in the settings of major trauma. It aims to control hemorrhage and prevent coagulopathy prior to the development of the trauma triad of death (hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy). The components of DCR include: • Permissive hypotension until definitive surgical control • Minimizing crystalloid-based resuscitation • Early use of blood products (PRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) in the ratio of 1:1:1 • Use of hemostatic agents such as tranexamic acid, recombinant factor 7a, prothrombin complex concentrates. DCR has the following advantages: • Minimizes the impact of trauma-induced coagulopathy • Limits blood product waste • Reduces the complications that occur with aggressive crystalloid resuscitation.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs has a significant role in the mortality reduction of trauma patients based on the CRASH-2 trial?
questions.explanation: The CRASH-2 trial has shown mortality reduction in bleeding trauma patients by early use of tranexamic acid (preferably within the first 3 hours) with a loading dose of 1 g over 10 minutes and then infusion of 1 g over 8 hours.

questions.question: In a patient with massive hemorrhage, damage control surgery is being performed. What does this consist of?
questions.explanation: Damage Control Surgery refers to performing limited surgical intervention in order to arrest hemorrhage, control sepsis, and protect from further injury. This concept of tailoring the operation to match the patient's physiology and staged procedures to prevent physiological exhaustion is called Damage Control Surgery. Furthermore, definitive repairs are delayed and not until the patient is hemodynamically stable and physiologically capable of sustaining the procedure. Crystalloid and colloid infusions are limited in order to avoid dilutional coagulopathy. The term Damage Control Surgery is borrowed from the military, which ensures the continued functioning of a damaged ship above conducting complete repairs, which would prevent a rapid return to battle.

questions.question: A young man sustained multiple injuries following a road traffic accident. On examination, his pulse rate is 100/min and BP is 85/60 mmHg. He is diagnosed with a pelvic fracture and is suspected to have retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of damage control surgery
options.B: Definitive repair of injuries is done 12-24 hours after phase III
options.C: Internal iliac artery ligation is done in phase II
options.D: Hypothermia and acidosis are corrected in phase I

questions.explanation: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of Damage Control Surgery. Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitive surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. It consists of three phases: Phase I - Initial Exploration: This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination. Phase II - Secondary Resuscitation: This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis. Phase III - Definitive Operation: It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of the trauma triad of death?
questions.explanation: Shock is not considered to be a component of the trauma triad of death. The trauma triad of death is a combination of clinical features that are seen in exsanguinating trauma patients and contribute to the majority of trauma-related mortality and morbidities. The triad includes: • Hypothermia • Coagulopathy • Acidosis. During the resuscitation phase of trauma, adequate precautions should be taken to prevent the development of these features. • Hypothermia is prevented by maintenance of ambient temperature within the patient's room, usage of prewarmed IV fluids, blankets, etc. • Coagulopathy can be prevented by judicious use of IV crystalloids (<1-1.5 liters), early initiation of blood and blood products, usage of tranexamic acid, etc. • Acidosis can be prevented by correction of shock, ensuring adequate oxygenation, usage of sodium bicarbonate, etc.
